so, i7 isnt better than i5 yet?
@aseba Depends on what you need
well.. that's my point, why should I buy the i7?, or the i5?
of course the Air is nice if you have the money... bigger resolution available, SSD, lighter ... that's an easy decision
@Josesordo use http://ark.intel.com/ to find CPU data
I'm looking for the new macbookpro 13''.. I wondering if it would be a good idea to switch or to stay on my c2d
But the new 13" MBPs don't have quad core i5 CPUs, only dual core
Also, you'd only have the Intel integrated graphics, which are a bit worse than the nvidia 320M
I don't need graphics. I just code.. jeje..
No SSD, no higher resolution, no matte display...
Yep, but I can buy an SSD for my laptop and it's done
I wouldn't upgrade, instead you could invest some money in a SSD drive... it's a big performance jump many people say
what i'm going to miss from the pro switching to an air is the backlight on the keyboard
well.. my real thinking is switching to an 13'' Air, or keep my pro and buy an SSD
bigger resolution?
AFAIK the 13" air is also available with  1440x900 resolution
@josesordo Córdoba.. ejejejejje.. there are lots of other cities tho.. I'm from the south, near bariloche
what is the differente between i5 and i7 technically?

yep: http://www.apple.com/macbookair/specs-13inch.html
@aseba oh.. a Argentina boy =) .. Cordoba or Buenos Aires?
@josesordo jajaja I'm from Argentina.. I own an apple... Not rich at all
There's a differnce between beign a fanatic and knowing thats better in some way
@aseba ah ok.. if I wanna travel to Argentina, what city you recommend me? =)

Back to the topic. i5 is almost always the correct choice. cost vs performance is better in the i5 - and the i7 isn't always that much 'faster' anyway. Laptop, not sure on the power usage between the two, but i7 would probably be higher (also by how much i have no idea). If you know you need the i7, or you have money to waste sure i7, but theres nothing wrong with the i5 IMHO.
i7 has always been better, if anything i5 has been catching up. My point is that i7 from i5 is not a big enough leap.

@Josesordo according to macrumors.com the two i7 models will be http://ark.intel.com/Product.aspx?id=50067&code=Intel%C2%AE+Core%E2%84%A2+i7-2720QM+Processor+(6M+Cache,+2.20+GHz) and http://ark.intel.com/Product.aspx?id=52219&code=Intel%C2%AE+Core%E2%84%A2+i7-2630QM+Processor+(6M+Cache,+2.00+GHz)
